articles.headline: Supreme Court Ruling Allows Strip Searches for Any Arrest
articles.snippet: The court ruled that people arrested for any offense, however minor, may be forced to strip before being jailed, even if there is no suspicion of contraband.
articles.abstract: The court ruled that people arrested for any offense, however minor, may be forced to strip before being jailed, even if there is no suspicion of contraband.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday ruled by a 5-to-4 vote that officials may strip-search people arrested for any offense, however minor, before admitting them to jails even if the officials have no reason to suspect the presence of contraband.

articles.headline: Investors Are Looking to Buy Homes by the Thousands
articles.snippet: With house prices still down, some large investors are creating huge portfolios by buying thousands of homes at deep discounts and then renting them out.
articles.abstract: With house prices still down, some large investors are creating huge portfolios by buying thousands of homes at deep discounts and then renting them out.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIVERSIDE, Calif. — At least 20 times a day, Alan Hladik walks into a fixer-upper and tries to figure out if it is worth buying.

articles.headline: A Favored Son Returns to Uphill Battle in Nebraska
articles.snippet: After 12 years away, Bob Kerrey has found himself recast as a carpetbagger in his native state.
articles.abstract: After 12 years away, Bob Kerrey has found himself recast as a carpetbagger in his native state.
articles.lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — Bob Kerrey, the former governor and two-term senator from Nebraska, has returned to his native state after a decade in New York City to try to reclaim his Senate seat.

articles.headline: Small Banks Shift Charters to Avoid U.S. as Regulator
articles.snippet: An increasing number of the nation’s savings and loan associations are avoiding some federal oversight by becoming credit unions or switching to a state charter.
articles.abstract: An increasing number of the nation’s savings and loan associations are avoiding some federal oversight by becoming credit unions or switching to a state charter.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small community bank in New Hampshire found a demand from its regulator last month just too much.

articles.headline: Where Housing Once Boomed, Recovery Lags
articles.snippet: The official statistics say that the national economy has been growing for almost three years, but there is scant evidence of renewed prosperity in places like Prince George’s County, Md.
articles.abstract: The official statistics say that the national economy has been growing for almost three years, but there is scant evidence of renewed prosperity in places like Prince George’s County, Md.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLINTON, Md. — Half a decade has passed since crowds of lunchtime workers regularly packed the Fish Market restaurant, a popular fixture of this southern Maryland crossroads known by the lighthouse on its roof.

articles.headline: Libyan Militias Turn to Politics, a Volatile Mix
articles.snippet: Local brigades claim the mantle of guardians, but many civilians worry that they could bully voters, suppress votes or otherwise dominate upcoming elections.
articles.abstract: Local brigades claim the mantle of guardians, but many civilians worry that they could bully voters, suppress votes or otherwise dominate upcoming elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — The militia leaders who have turned post-Qaddafi Libya into a patchwork of semiautonomous fiefs are now plunging into politics, raising fears that their armed brigades could undermine elections intended to lay the foundation of a new democracy.

articles.headline: A Satellite System That Could End Circling Above the Airport
articles.snippet: Airlines and airports are testing a guidance system that could reduce congestion and fuel consumption by allowing planes to take a more direct route to the runway.
articles.abstract: Airlines and airports are testing a guidance system that could reduce congestion and fuel consumption by allowing planes to take a more direct route to the runway.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Capt. Mike Adams demonstrated what the future will look like at the nation’s airports as he pulled back on the throttles of his Boeing 737 flight simulator, setting the engines on idle to glide smoothly from his cruising altitude all the way down to the runway.
